block.text: Skip to content Ars Technica home Sections Forum Subscribe Search AI Biz & IT Cars Culture Gaming Health Policy Science Security Space Tech Feature Reviews AI Biz & IT Cars Culture Gaming Health Policy Science Security Space Tech Forum Subscribe Theme HyperLight Day & Night Dark System Sign In Ars Technica homepage Grid Classic Grid List Neutron Star Classic Grid List Neutron Star grid settings Featured LEAP Jef Raskin’s cul-de-sac and the quest for the humane computer “He wanted to make [computers] more usable and friendly to people who weren't geeks.” Cameron Kaiser – 9/12/2025 | 62 60 years after Gemini, newly processed images reveal incredible details "It's that level of risk that they were taking. I think that's what really hit home." Eric Berger – 9/13/2025 | 0 Scientists: It’s do or die time for America’s primacy exploring the Solar System "When you turn off those spacecraft’s radio receivers, there's no way to turn them back on." Stephen Clark – 9/12/2025 | 54 RFK Jr.’s CDC may limit COVID shots to 75 and up, claim they killed kids A battle is brewing over mRNA vaccines, which could intensify backlash against Kennedy. Beth Mole – 9/12/2025 | 134 Modder injects AI dialogue into 2002’s Animal Crossing using memory hack Unofficial mod lets classic Nintendo GameCube title use AI chatbots with amusing results. Benj Edwards – 9/12/2025 | 17 60 years after Gemini, newly processed images reveal incredible details "It's that level of risk that they were taking. I think that's what really hit home." Eric Berger – 9/13/2025 | 0 Scientists: It’s do or die time for America’s primacy exploring the Solar System "When you turn off those spacecraft’s radio receivers, there's no way to turn them back on." Stephen Clark – 9/12/2025 | 54 RFK Jr.’s CDC may limit COVID shots to 75 and up, claim they killed kids A battle is brewing over mRNA vaccines, which could intensify backlash against Kennedy. Beth Mole – 9/12/2025 | 134 Modder injects AI dialogue into 2002’s Animal Crossing using memory hack Unofficial mod lets classic Nintendo GameCube title use AI chatbots with amusing results. Benj Edwards – 9/12/2025 | 17 Feds try to dodge lawsuit against their bogus climate report Meanwhile, Congress is trying to keep serious scientists from weighing in. John Timmer – 9/12/2025 | 30 After Kirk shooting, Utah governor calls social media a “cancer.” Will we treat it like one? We did not evolve to handle this, Utah governor says. Nate Anderson – 9/12/2025 | 223 Electric vehicle sales grew 25% worldwide but just 6% in North America North America has bought 1.3 million EVs this year; China has bought 7.6 million. Jonathan M. Gitlin – 9/12/2025 | 114 California bill lets renters escape exclusive deals between ISPs and landlords Bill author says law "gives this industry an opportunity to treat people fairly." Jon Brodkin – 9/12/2025 | 47 Education report calling for ethical AI use contains over 15 fake sources Experts find fake sources in Canadian government report that took 18 months to complete. Benj Edwards – 9/12/2025 | 103 Over three decades later, Nintendo remembers the Virtual Boy exists A $100 replica Switch dock or $25 cardboard sleeve is needed to play the 3D re-releases. Kyle Orland – 9/12/2025 | 58 Featured Build your own Wrapped? Spotify peeved after 10,000 users sold data to build AI tools Spotify sent a warning to stop data sales, but developers say they never got it. Ashley Belanger – 9/10/2025 | 82 New pathway engineered into plants lets them suck up more CO₂ Engineered pathway lets carbon be plugged directly into key metabolic pathways. John Timmer – 9/12/2025 | 85 Most Read 1. Rocket Report: Russia’s rocket engine predicament; 300th launch to the ISS 2. Child dies of horrifying measles complication in Los Angeles 3. RFK Jr.’s CDC may limit COVID shots to 75 and up, claim they killed kids 4. Pentagon begins deploying new satellite network to link sensors with shooters 5. Small, affordable, efficient: A lot to like about the 2026 Nissan Leaf Customize Small, affordable, efficient: A lot to like about the 2026 Nissan Leaf Smaller on the outside, bigger on the inside, and it goes farther on a single charge. Jonathan M. Gitlin – 9/12/2025 | 157 Ex-DVD company employee gets 4 years for leaking Spider-Man Blu-ray Man agreed to return more than 1,000 stolen DVDs to his former employer. Ashley Belanger – 9/12/2025 | 46 Microsoft dodges EU fine by unbundling Teams from Office EU probe came after complaint by Slack in 2020. Financial Times – 9/12/2025 | 66 Rocket Report: Russia’s rocket engine predicament; 300th launch to the ISS North Korea test-fired a powerful new solid rocket motor for its next-generation ICBM. Stephen Clark – 9/12/2025 | 80 OpenAI and Microsoft sign preliminary deal to revise partnership terms Companies work to finalize terms as OpenAI pursues for-profit restructuring. Benj Edwards – 9/11/2025 | 35 Child dies of horrifying measles complication in Los Angeles SSPE is a rare but always fatal disease that destroys a child's brain. Beth Mole – 9/11/2025 | 195 NASA found intriguing rocks on Mars, so where does that leave Mars Sample Return? "I have to look at dollars, and I have to look at time, and I have to look at return." Eric Berger – 9/11/2025 | 100 Latest TRON: Ares trailer takes us back to 1982 "Our worlds are more connected than anyone knows." Jennifer Ouellette – 9/11/2025 | 73 New black hole merger bolsters Hawking area theorem Physicists spliced merger's gravitational signal into isolated frequencies to determine surface areas. Jennifer Ouellette – 9/11/2025 | 63 Ted Cruz AI bill could let firms bribe Trump to avoid safety laws, critics warn Ted Cruz won’t give up fight to block states from regulating AI. Ashley Belanger – 9/11/2025 | 54 35 percent of VMware workloads expected to migrate elsewhere by 2028 “We are all addicted to hypervisors, and that needs to change." Scharon Harding – 9/11/2025 | 90 Is Hollow Knight: Silksong too hard? Well, it depends on what you mean by “hard.” The Ars Difficulty Matrix™ helps us analyze the many dimensions of Silksong 's challenges. Kyle Orland – 9/11/2025 | 190 Gmail gets a dedicated place to track all your purchases Gmail reorganizes its order-tracking and promotion filters ahead of the holiday season. Ryan Whitwam – 9/11/2025 | 61 The US is now the largest investor in commercial spyware And new countries are linked to the dangerous software. WIRED – 9/11/2025 | 44 Pentagon begins deploying new satellite network to link sensors with shooters "This is the first time we'll have a space layer fully integrated into our warfighting operations." Stephen Clark – 9/10/2025 | 62 Court rejects Verizon claim that selling location data without consent is legal Verizon and T-Mobile lost, but AT&T beat the FCC. SCOTUS may have to step in. Jon Brodkin – 9/10/2025 | 42 After Ukrainian testing, drone-detection radar doubles range with simple software patch Even mobile radars are now software upgradeable. Nate Anderson – 9/10/2025 | 115 HBO Max is “way underpriced,” Warner Bros. Discovery CEO says People used to pay $55 a month for TV, Zaslav recalls. Scharon Harding – 9/10/2025 | 253 Ousted CDC director to testify before Senate after RFK Jr. called her a liar Monarez said she was fired for not pre-approving vaccine recommendations from a dubious panel. Beth Mole – 9/10/2025 | 78 Senator blasts Microsoft for making default Windows vulnerable to “Kerberoasting” Wyden says default use of RC4 cipher led to last year's breach of health giant Ascension. Dan Goodin – 9/10/2025 | 112 One of Google’s new Pixel 10 AI features has already been removed The Pixel 10 Daily Hub has vanished, but Google says it will come back when it's ready. Ryan Whitwam – 9/10/2025 | 35 Developers joke about “coding like cavemen” as AI service suffers major outage Anthropic outage takes down AI tools some developers rely on to create software. Benj Edwards – 9/10/2025 | 96 Can we please keep our broadband money, Republican governor asks Trump admin Governor worries Trump won't let states spend entire $42 billion broadband fund. Jon Brodkin – 9/10/2025 | 73 Load more Ars Technica has been separating the signal from the noise for over 25 years. With our unique combination of technical savvy and wide-ranging interest in the technological arts and sciences, Ars is the trusted source in a sea of information. After all, you don’t need to know everything, only what’s important.
